natural problem: Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent.
natural solution: If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P r n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "r = 0.12"
and h2 : "t = 4"
and h3 : "A_annual = P * (1 + r) powr t"
and h4 : "A_quarterly = P * (1 + r/4) powr (4*t)"
shows  "A_quarterly - A_annual = 187.12"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P r n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "r = 0.12"
and h2 : "t = 4"
and h3 : "A_annual = P * (1 + r) powr t"
and h4 : "A_quarterly = P * (1 + r/4) powr (4*t)"
shows  "A_quarterly - A_annual = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If you invest $6000 at an annual interest rate of 12% for 4 years, compare the total amount of money you will have if the interest is compounded annually versus quarterly. What is the difference between the two amounts? The final answer is $187.12.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes loan amount_annual amount_quarterly :: real
assumes h0 : "loan = 6000"
and h1 : "amount_annual = loan * (1 + 0.12) powr 4"
and h2 : "amount_quarterly = loan * (1 + 0.12 / 4) powr (4 * 4)"
shows  "amount_quarterly - amount_annual = 187.12"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes loan amount_annual amount_quarterly :: real
assumes h0 : "loan = 6000"
and h1 : "amount_annual = loan * (1 + 0.12) powr 4"
and h2 : "amount_quarterly = loan * (1 + 0.12 / 4) powr (4 * 4)"
shows  "amount_quarterly - amount_annual = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If a loan of $6000 is compounded annually at a rate of 12%, the amount after 4 years is $amount_{annual}$. If the same loan is compounded quarterly at the same rate, the amount after 4 years is $amount_{quarterly}$. What is the difference between $amount_{quarterly}$ and $amount_{annual}$? The final answer is $187.12.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P R n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "R = 0.12"
and h2 : "t = 4"
and h3 : "n = 4"
and h4 : "A = P * (1 + R / n) powr (n * t)"
and h5 : "B = P * (1 + R) powr t"
shows  "A - B = 187.12"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P R n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "R = 0.12"
and h2 : "t = 4"
and h3 : "n = 4"
and h4 : "A = P * (1 + R / n) powr (n * t)"
and h5 : "B = P * (1 + R) powr t"
shows  "A - B = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Calculate the difference between the amount of money in an account after 4 years under two different compound interest formulas. The account starts with $6000. The first formula compounds 4 times per year with an annual interest rate of 12%. The second formula compounds once per year with the same annual interest rate. The final difference between the two amounts is $187.12.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P A Q :: real and n m :: nat
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "0.12 = A"
and h2 : "n = 4"
and h3 : "m = 4"
and h4 : "P * (1 + A / m) pow (m * n) = Q"
and h5 : "P * (1 + A) pow n = Q"
shows  "Q - Q = 187.12" (* difference in total owed amount *)
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P A Q :: real and n m :: nat
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "0.12 = A"
and h2 : "n = 4"
and h3 : "m = 4"
and h4 : "P * (1 + A / m) pow (m * n) = Q"
and h5 : "P * (1 + A) pow n = Q"
shows  "Q - Q = 187.12" (* difference in total owed amount *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given an initial loan amount of $6000, find the difference in the total amount owed after four years under two different compounding scenarios: one where interest is compounded annually at a rate of 12%, and one where interest is compounded quarterly at the same annual rate. The final answer is $187.12.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes principal :: real
and annual_rate :: real
and quarterly_rate :: real
and years :: real
and future_value_annual :: real
and future_value_quarterly :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "annual_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "quarterly_rate = annual_rate / 4"
and h3 : "years = 4"
and h4 : "future_value_annual = principal * (1 + annual_rate) powr years"
and h5 : "future_value_quarterly = principal * (1 + quarterly_rate) powr (4 * years)"
shows  "round (future_value_quarterly - future_value_annual) = 187.12"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes principal :: real
and annual_rate :: real
and quarterly_rate :: real
and years :: real
and future_value_annual :: real
and future_value_quarterly :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "annual_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "quarterly_rate = annual_rate / 4"
and h3 : "years = 4"
and h4 : "future_value_annual = principal * (1 + annual_rate) powr years"
and h5 : "future_value_quarterly = principal * (1 + quarterly_rate) powr (4 * years)"
shows  "round (future_value_quarterly - future_value_annual) = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Suppose you invest $6,000 at an annual interest rate of 12%. Calculate the difference in future value after 4 years if the interest is compounded annually versus quarterly. Round your answer to two decimal places. The final answer is $187.12.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes principal :: real
and annual_rate :: real
and years :: real
and quarterly_rate :: real
and annual_compound_interest :: real
and quarterly_compound_interest :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "annual_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "years = 4"
and h3 : "quarterly_rate = annual_rate / 4"
and h4 : "annual_compound_interest = principal * (1 + annual_rate) powr years"
and h5 : "quarterly_compound_interest = principal * (1 + quarterly_rate) powr (4 * years)"
shows  "quarterly_compound_interest - annual_compound_interest = 187.12"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes principal :: real
and annual_rate :: real
and years :: real
and quarterly_rate :: real
and annual_compound_interest :: real
and quarterly_compound_interest :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "annual_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "years = 4"
and h3 : "quarterly_rate = annual_rate / 4"
and h4 : "annual_compound_interest = principal * (1 + annual_rate) powr years"
and h5 : "quarterly_compound_interest = principal * (1 + quarterly_rate) powr (4 * years)"
shows  "quarterly_compound_interest - annual_compound_interest = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Suppose you invest $6000 at an annual interest rate of 12%. Compare the compound interest after 4 years when the interest is compounded annually and when it is compounded quarterly. What is the difference in the compound interest amounts? The final answer is $187.12.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P r n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "r = 0.12"
and h2 : "n = 4"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1, 4} \<longrightarrow> (1 + r/n) powr (n * t) \<ge> 0"
and h4 : "t = 4"
shows  "abs (((1 + r/1) powr (1 * t) - 1) * P - ((1 + r/4) powr (4 * t) - 1) * P) = 187.12"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P r n t :: real
assumes h0 : "P = 6000"
and h1 : "r = 0.12"
and h2 : "n = 4"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1, 4} \<longrightarrow> (1 + r/n) powr (n * t) \<ge> 0"
and h4 : "t = 4"
shows  "abs (((1 + r/1) powr (1 * t) - 1) * P - ((1 + r/4) powr (4 * t) - 1) * P) = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A bank account has an initial balance of $6000$ and an annual interest rate of $12\%$. The interest is compounded either annually ($n=1$) or quarterly ($n=4$). After $4$ years, find the absolute difference between the final balances of the two accounts when the interest is compounded annually and quarterly. The final answer is $187.12$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes principal :: real
and annual_interest_rate :: real
and quarterly_interest_rate :: real
and quarterly_compound :: real
and annual_compound :: real
and difference :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "annual_interest_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "quarterly_interest_rate = annual_interest_rate / 4"
and h3 : "annual_compound = principal * (1 + annual_interest_rate) powr 4"
and h4 : "quarterly_compound = principal * (1 + quarterly_interest_rate) powr 16"
and h5 : "difference = quarterly_compound - annual_compound"
shows  "round (difference * 100) / 100 = 187.12"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes principal :: real
and annual_interest_rate :: real
and quarterly_interest_rate :: real
and quarterly_compound :: real
and annual_compound :: real
and difference :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "annual_interest_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "quarterly_interest_rate = annual_interest_rate / 4"
and h3 : "annual_compound = principal * (1 + annual_interest_rate) powr 4"
and h4 : "quarterly_compound = principal * (1 + quarterly_interest_rate) powr 16"
and h5 : "difference = quarterly_compound - annual_compound"
shows  "round (difference * 100) / 100 = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: An initial investment of $6000 is compounded with an annual interest rate of 12%. Calculate the difference between the future value of the investment when compounded quarterly and when compounded annually. Round the result to two decimal places. The final answer is $187.12.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes loan interest_rate quarterly_compounds annually_compounds :: real
assumes h0 : "loan = 6000"
and h1 : "interest_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "quarterly_compounds = loan * (1 + interest_rate / 4) ^ 16"
and h3 : "annually_compounds = loan * (1 + interest_rate) ^ 4"
shows  "round (quarterly_compounds - annually_compounds) = 187.12"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes loan interest_rate quarterly_compounds annually_compounds :: real
assumes h0 : "loan = 6000"
and h1 : "interest_rate = 0.12"
and h2 : "quarterly_compounds = loan * (1 + interest_rate / 4) ^ 16"
and h3 : "annually_compounds = loan * (1 + interest_rate) ^ 4"
shows  "round (quarterly_compounds - annually_compounds) = 187.12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A loan of $6000 is taken at an interest rate of 12% per year. Calculate the difference between the amount to be repaid if the interest is compounded quarterly for 4 years and if the interest is compounded annually for 4 years. Round your answer to 2 decimal places. The final answer is $187.12.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes principal r_quarterly r_annual n_quarterly n_annual :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "r_quarterly = 0.12 / 4"
and h2 : "r_annual = 0.12"
and h3 : "n_quarterly = 4 * 4"
and h4 : "n_annual = 4"
and h5 : "principal * ((1 + r_quarterly) powr n_quarterly) = principal * (1 + r_annual) powr n_annual + 187.12"
shows  "187.12 = (\<lambda>x. (principal * (1 + r_quarterly) powr n_quarterly) - (principal * (1 + r_annual) powr n_annual)) principal"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Joanie takes a $\$6,\!000$ loan to pay for her car.  The annual interest rate on the loan is $12\%$.  She makes no payments for 4 years, but has to pay back all the money she owes at the end of 4 years. How much more money will she owe if the interest compounds quarterly than if the interest compounds annually?  Express your answer as a dollar value to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$187.12
 ### Proof
 If the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\left(1 + \frac{0.12}{4}\right)^{4\cdot 4}(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!628.24.\]  If it compounds annually, she owes \[(1+0.12)^4(\$6,\!000)\approx \$9,\!441.12.\]  Therefore, if the interest compounds quarterly, she owes \[\$9,\!628.24 - \$9,\!441.12 = \boxed{\$187.12}\text{ more.
 }\]
 *)

theorem
fixes principal r_quarterly r_annual n_quarterly n_annual :: real
assumes h0 : "principal = 6000"
and h1 : "r_quarterly = 0.12 / 4"
and h2 : "r_annual = 0.12"
and h3 : "n_quarterly = 4 * 4"
and h4 : "n_annual = 4"
and h5 : "principal * ((1 + r_quarterly) powr n_quarterly) = principal * (1 + r_annual) powr n_annual + 187.12"
shows  "187.12 = (\<lambda>x. (principal * (1 + r_quarterly) powr n_quarterly) - (principal * (1 + r_annual) powr n_annual)) principal"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Suppose you invest $6000 in two accounts. One account pays 12% annual interest, compounded quarterly, while the other account pays 12% annual interest, compounded annually. After four years, the difference in the amounts in the two accounts is $187.12. Confirm that this difference is indeed $187.12.
